Notes: Major I chord with complete diatonic extensions. Unique overtone signature: perfect 4th/11th AND major 7th. Removed non-diatonic I+, I7, chromatic bass notes. All extensions from major scale only.
Minor ii chord with all diatonic extensions. Essential for ii-V-I progressions. Standard min7 quality. All extensions from major scale perspective. Removed non-diatonic ii+, ii° variants.
Minor iii chord with unique overtone signature: b2nd/11th AND perfect fifth. Only chord possessing both intervals. Standard min7 quality. Removed non-diatonic iii+ variations.

Major IV chord with unique overtone signature: #4/11th (tritone) AND major 7th. Critical for plagal cadences. Lydian characteristic with raised 11th in some contexts. Removed non-diatonic IV+ variants.
Major V chord with unique overtone signature: b7th AND major 3rd (frames tritone). Primary dominant function. V7 is diatonic. Essential for authentic cadences and ii-V-I progressions.
Minor vi chord with unique overtone signature: b6th AND natural 9th. Relative minor relationship to I. Essential for vi-IV-I-V progressions. Deceptive cadence destination.
Half-diminished vii chord (B-D-F-A in C major). Leading tone function. viiø7 is diatonic. NOT fully diminished (vii°7 would have Ab, non-diatonic). Essential for smooth voice leading to I.
Applied dominant I7 (C7 in C major). Functions as V7/IV. Non-diatonic due to b7th. All dominant alterations permitted. NO major 7th chords. Chromatic bass notes allowed.
Applied half-diminished iii chord. Non-diatonic alteration of diatonic iii. Functions as viiø7/vi or ii7b5/ii. All diminished extensions permitted. Chromatic bass notes allowed.
Secondary dominant II7 = V7/V (D7 in C major). Essential for tonicization of V. All dominant alterations and chromatic bass notes permitted. Major 3rd + b7th required.
Applied half-diminished #iv chord (F#ø7 in C major). Functions as viiø7/V. Leading tone chord to V. Non-diatonic due to #4. All diminished extensions permitted.
Secondary dominant III7 = V7/vi (E7 in C major). Tonicizes vi chord. Major III is non-diatonic. All dominant alterations permitted. Chromatic bass notes allowed.
Applied fully diminished #v chord. Functions as leading tone to vi. Contains diminished 7th interval (double-flat note). All diminished extensions permitted. Chromatic bass notes allowed.
Secondary dominant VI7 = V7/ii (A7 in C major). Tonicizes ii chord. Major VI is non-diatonic. Essential for ii-V progressions in ii. All dominant alterations permitted.
Applied fully diminished #i chord. Functions as leading tone to ii. Chromatic passing chord. Non-diatonic due to #1. All diminished extensions permitted.
Secondary dominant VII7 = V7/iii (B7 in C major). Tonicizes iii chord. Major VII is non-diatonic. Less common but theoretically valid. All dominant alterations permitted.
Applied fully diminished #ii chord. Functions as leading tone to iii. Chromatic passing function. Non-diatonic due to #2. All diminished extensions permitted.

Dominant V chord in minor key from harmonic minor (raised ^7). Essential for V-i authentic cadence. V7b9 common due to harmonic minor's b2 interval. Bass notes from combined minor scales (1,2,b3,4,5,b6,6,b7,7).
Fully diminished vii chord from harmonic minor. Contains diminished 7th (G#-F in A minor). Strong leading tone function to i. Different from major key viiø. Bass notes from combined minor scales.

Minor tonic with permutations from all three minor scales. i7 (natural minor), imaj7 (melodic minor), i6/ib6 (natural/melodic). Bass notes from scale degree union (1,2,b3,4,5,b6,6,b7,7). Central to minor key harmony.
Half-diminished ii chord from natural minor. Essential for iiø-V-i progressions in minor. Contains b5 interval characteristic of minor key harmony. Bass notes from combined minor scales.
Major bIII chord from natural minor (Eb in C minor). Relative major of minor key. Essential for bIII-bVI-bVII-i progressions. Major quality distinguishes from major key iii.
Minor iv chord from natural/harmonic minor. ivmaj7 possible from melodic minor. Plagal cadence in minor (iv-i). Distinguished from major key IV. Bass notes from combined minor scales.
Minor v chord from natural minor (Gm in C minor). Contrasts with V(7) from harmonic minor. Modal v-i cadence. Less leading tone tension than V-i. Bass notes from combined minor scales.
Major bVI chord from natural minor (Ab in C minor). Essential for bVI-bVII-i progressions. Modal mixture when borrowed into major key. Characteristic of minor key tonality.
Major bVII chord from natural minor (Bb in C minor). Subtonic function - steps down to tonic. bVII7 can be dom7. Essential for modal progressions and rock harmony.

Academic edge cases and advanced harmonic structures: It+6 (Italian augmented 6th - Puccini examples), Fr+6 (French aug6 - Debussy), Ger+6 (German aug6 - Beethoven Sym 9), N6 (Neapolitan - Chopin), Tristan (Wagner half-dim resolution), CT+7 (Common tone aug7), Myst (Scriabin Mystic chord), BACH motif, Petr (Petrushka chord), ChromMed (Chromatic mediants), PolyCh (Polychords), BiTon (Bitonal structures), Octat (Octatonic collections), dim/wht (Diminished-whole tone), h-wht (Half-whole scales), Rite/Salome/Elektra (Specific 20th century sonorities), DoubLead (Double leading tone), Comm7 (Common tone 7th). See Kostka-Payne Tonal Harmony, Schoenberg Theory of Harmony, When in Rome Corpus academic analyses.
